monday.details: Standard office hours. Focus on tasks.
Short and restorative to fit post-office fatigue.

tuesday.details: 75 mins total including travel/buffer. Back home/showered by 9:30 AM to start work comfortably.
Work from home. Stand up periodically.
Focus on Phase 1: Offensive API Security.

wednesday.details: Short and restorative to fit post-office fatigue.

thursday.details: Phase 1.5: VDP Hunt or Lab Project.

friday.details: 25 mins—quick morning session before work start.
Work from home. Wrap up weekly tasks.
Flexible time for Labs or Capstone.

saturday.details: 90 mins total, flexible end time since no work constraint.
Long session: Deep work on Capstone or VDP.

sunday.details: Total rest—no workouts, prioritize sleep/recovery for weekly reset.

warmup.title: Standard Warm-Up
warmup.description: Mandatory before every session: Builds mobility/agility baseline safely, preps for all goals without clashing schedules.

exercises.name: Light Cardio
exercises.form: Jog in place or jumping jacks. Steady pace to break sweat.
exercises.why: Elevates heart rate for endurance/sprint readiness, adaptable home/gym.

exercises.name: Neck CARs
exercises.why: Enhances head movement/clarity for chase/combat memorization.

exercises.name: Cat-Cow
exercises.form: On all fours, arch/round back with breath.
exercises.why: Spine mobility for balance in climbs/carries.

exercises.name: Shoulder Dislocates
exercises.why: Shoulder range for pulling/punching in self-protection.

exercises.name: World's Greatest Stretch
exercises.why: Opens hips for agility/momentum shifts.

exercises.name: Leg Swings
exercises.why: Loosens legs for sprints/labor demands.

exercises.name: Bodyweight Squats
exercises.form: Feet shoulder-width, sit back, knees track toes.
exercises.why: Primes lower body/core for strength/endurance.

light_recovery.title: Light Recovery
light_recovery.description: Goal: Healing/mobility focus—supports quick recovery for multiple efforts, fits office evenings/WFH mornings without strain. (25 mins total)

circuit.name: Bird-Dogs
circuit.form: Extend opposite arm/leg, hips level, core braced.
circuit.why: Builds core stability for balance in chases/climbs.

circuit.name: Side Plank
circuit.form: Straight body line, no hip sag.

circuit.name: Glute Bridges
circuit.form: Feet flat, lift hips squeezing glutes, drive through heels.
circuit.why: Glute activation for sprint/power in labor.

circuit.name: Couch Stretch
circuit.form: Knee down, foot against wall, lean forward.

circuit.name: Figure-Four Stretch
circuit.form: Cross ankle over knee, pull thigh in.

strength_pulling.title: Strength & Pulling Focus
strength_pulling.description: Goal: Raw functional strength for labor/carrying/climbing/combat—directly builds grip/resilience for jerrycans/barrows/holding off attackers. (75 mins)

exercises.name: Barbell Back Squats
exercises.form: Bar on upper back, feet shoulder-width, descend to parallel with core braced, drive up through heels.
exercises.why: Leg/core power for sustained labor/sprints over 1-2km. Progress: Add weight when 2 reps in reserve.

exercises.name: Bent-Over Barbell Rows
exercises.form: Hinge hips, flat back, pull bar to lower ribs, squeeze shoulder blades.
exercises.why: Back pulling strength for climbing/ledges/bodyweight pulls. Progress: Add weight at full reps with control.

exercises.name: Dumbbell Floor Press
exercises.form: Lie on floor, press from chest, elbows at 45 degrees.
exercises.why: Pushing toughness for self-protection in 4v1 scenarios. Progress: Increase weight gradually.

exercises.name: Push-Ups
exercises.form: Straight body, chest to floor, full range.
exercises.why: Additional upper body pushing resilience for combat or pushing obstacles.

exercises.name: Farmers Walk
exercises.why: Grip/endurance for carrying loads without failure.

exercises.name: Band Pull-Aparts
exercises.form: Hold band at chest, pull apart to sides.
exercises.why: Shoulder health/toughness for repeated efforts.

combat_conditioning.title: Combat Conditioning & Sprint
combat_conditioning.description: Goal: Fight stamina/sprint capacity—trains for chases (2-3km sprint, 10km jog) and holding off attackers with clarity/recovery. (75 mins)

exercises.name: Punching Bag Intervals
exercises.details: 20 mins total. 30 secs all-out combos, 90 secs active rest (light footwork).
exercises.form: Hands up, pivot feet, move head.
exercises.why: Power/mental toughness for 4v1 deterrence/escape.

exercises.name: Treadmill Intervals
exercises.details: Weeks 1-4: 400m hard run, 90 secs walk x6; progress to 600m (5-8), 800m (9-12).
exercises.why: Builds sustained effort for escapes/long distances.

exercises.name: Farmers Holds (Grip Finisher)
exercises.why: Resilient grip for labor/confrontations.

agility_skill.title: Agility & Skill Synthesis
agility_skill.description: Goal: Integrate skills under fatigue—mimics real-world survival (multi-attacker, labor, climbs) for adaptability/body control. (90 mins)

exercises.name: Extended Warm-Up
exercises.why: Agility/mental clarity.

exercises.name: Inverted Rows (Skill Drill)
exercises.form: Pull chest to bar, slow 5-sec negative lower, body straight.
exercises.why: Bodyweight pulling for ledges/hanging emergencies.

exercises.name: Carries (Skill Drill)
exercises.why: Dexterity/grip for jerrycans/barrows over distance.

exercises.name: Capacity Challenge (AMRAP)
exercises.details: 15-20 mins. 15 Inverted Rows, 20 Bag Slams, 400m Run, 15 Barbell Back Squats. Rest 2 mins after full circuit.
exercises.why: Stop-start demands for protection/labor scenarios.

phases.title: Foundational DevOps & Server Admin
phases.description: Why: To fix your self-admitted weakness. This phase builds the "terminal muscle memory" required to operate in the headless (non-GUI) Linux environments where all professional targets (servers, APIs, containers) reside.

tasks.name: Skill: Terminal & Git Fluency
tasks.details:
What: Mastering core Linux and Git commands until they are muscle memory.
How to Practice ($0):
- Linux (Practice): Finish all levels of OverTheWire: Bandit. This is your #1 priority for core commands.
- Git (Practice): Create a GitHub repo. Practice the full workflow: git clone, git add ., git commit -m "msg", git push. Do this 20 times.
- Git (Learn): Use the Git Tower (Free Book) for a clear guide.
tasks.deliverable: A GitHub repository with a 100-commit history (even if just text files) to build muscle memory.
tasks.done: Definition of Done: You can finish a Bandit level and `git push` your notes without looking up the commands.

tasks.name: Project 1: Python Log Analyzer
tasks.details:
What: Turning a simple Bash one-liner into a professional, reusable Python tool. Demonstrates "Text-Fu" and practical scripting.
How to Practice ($0):
- Service Mgmt: On Debian VM, install Nginx. Control it (systemctl).
- Log Analysis: Read DigitalOcean grep/awk/sed Guide.
- Lab: TryHackMe 'Tinkerbell' Room.
- Python: Learn argparse and re modules.
tasks.deliverable: A new GitHub repo `log-analyzer.py`. Must use argparse (-f) and regex to parse Nginx log to JSON.
tasks.done: Definition of Done: Script runs from CLI, parses real /var/log/nginx/access.log, and prints clean JSON report.

phases.title: Offensive API Security & Tooling
phases.description: Why: To build your core specialization. This phase pivots from generic web hacking to the high-demand field of API-specific vulnerabilities.

tasks.name: Skill: API Hacking (Offensive Theory)
tasks.details:
What: Master OWASP API Top 10. Focus on Business Logic Flaws: API1 (BOLA), API5 (BFLA), API2 (Broken Auth).
How to Practice ($0):
- Study: Read OWASP API Top 10 Project docs.
- Practice (Mandatory): Complete all labs in PortSwigger Academy "API Security" module.
- Practice (Tools): Use Postman and Burp Suite Community.
- Lab: Explore vAPI (Vulnerable API) project.
tasks.deliverable: A document in your GitHub repo (API_NOTES.md) explaining BOLA, BFLA, and Broken Auth in your own words.
tasks.done: Definition of Done: Completed all Practitioner-level API security labs in PortSwigger Academy and can explain BOLA by heart.

tasks.name: Project 2: API Pentest Toolkit
tasks.details:
What: Building an extensible Python toolkit.
How to Practice ($0):
- Learn: Read requests library docs.
- Project: Build reusable Python script (api-toolkit.py) using argparse.
- Start with module_bola (iterates IDs).
- Add module_discovery (wordlist finder).
tasks.deliverable: New GitHub repo `api-pentest-toolkit` containing finished, modular tool. README.md explaining usage.
tasks.done: Definition of Done: Working, reusable Python script that runs at least two different 'attack modules' selected via CLI.

phases.title: The 'Real World' VDP Hunt
phases.description: Why: To validate skills on real infrastructure without competing against elite hackers. Focus on VDPs to build portfolio.

tasks.name: Skill: Strategic VDP Selection
tasks.details:
What: Finding targets not saturated by automation.
How to Practice ($0):
- Avoid Front Page: Don't pick top HackerOne programs.
- Find VDPs: Search for 'Vulnerability Disclosure Programs' offering Thanks/Swag (not cash).
- Self-Hosted: Look for self-managed programs on company websites.
tasks.deliverable: A list of 3 low-competition VDP targets.
tasks.done: Definition of Done: You have selected ONE specific VDP target for the next step.

tasks.name: Project: The 14-Day Deep Dive
tasks.details:
What: Applying 'Pattern Recognition' to a single target.
The Routine:
- Rule: Stick to ONE target for 2 weeks.
- Daily: 2 hours study feature, 2-3 hours active hunting.
- Focus: Map business logic. Look for where patterns (IDOR/BOLA) should exist.
tasks.deliverable: A valid vulnerability report (even P4/Low) or a detailed 'Attack Surface Map'.
tasks.done: Definition of Done: You have spent 14 days on one target and understand its business logic better than the developers.

phases.title: SDLC & Target Creation
phases.description: Why: To learn the 'Build It' part. You will build your own vulnerable target to understand a developer's logic.

tasks.name: Project 3: Build a Multi-Vuln API Lab
tasks.details:
What: Use Python Flask to create REST API with /login and user endpoints. Deliberately code flaws.
How to Practice ($0):
- Learn: Flask Quickstart docs.
- Flaw 1 (BOLA): /users/<id> endpoint must not check login match.
- Flaw 2 (BFLA): /admin/all_users checks login but not role.
- Flaw 3 (Mass Assignment): PATCH /profile allows updating "is_admin": true.
tasks.deliverable: New GitHub repo `multi-vuln-api-lab` with source code.
tasks.done: Definition of Done: API runs locally and is demonstrably vulnerable to BOLA, BFLA, and Mass Assignment.

tasks.name: Skill: Containerize Your Target
tasks.details:
What: Package your vulnerable API using Docker.
How to Practice ($0):
- Learn: Docker 'Get Started'.
- Project: Write Dockerfile and docker-compose.yml.
tasks.deliverable: Dockerfile and docker-compose.yml committed to repo.
tasks.done: Definition of Done: Vulnerable API runs successfully from a Docker container using `docker compose up`.

phases.title: Custom Exploit Dev & Reporting
phases.description: Why: To learn the 'Break It' part. Write custom exploit and document it professionally.

tasks.name: Skill: Custom Multi-Exploit Scripting
tasks.details:
What: Adapt api-pentest-toolkit or write new exploit.py to find all 3 vulnerabilities.
How to Practice ($0):
- Script: Login as low-privilege user.
- Exploit:
  1. Exploit BOLA to read user_B data.
  2. Exploit BFLA to access /admin.
  3. Exploit Mass Assignment to become admin.
tasks.deliverable: README.md with 'Exploitation Steps' and finished exploit.py.
tasks.done: Definition of Done: exploit.py successfully exploits all three vulnerabilities.

tasks.name: Project 4: Professional Vulnerability Report
tasks.details:
What: Creating a high-quality PDF report.
Content:
1. Executive Summary.
2. Technical Findings (one per bug).
3. Proof of Concept (exploit code/output).
4. Remediation (how to fix).
tasks.done: Definition of Done: Professional PDF report clearly explaining risk, impact, and solution.

phases.title: Standalone Project - JWT Security Lab
phases.description: Why: To tackle API2: Broken Authentication (JWT).

tasks.name: Skill: Build & Break a JWT API
tasks.details:
What: Use Flask and PyJWT to build API with JWT flaws.
How to Practice ($0):
- Build: /login (issues JWT) and /protected.
- Flaw 1 (alg:none): /protected accepts alg:none.
- Flaw 2 (Weak Secret): Use 'secret123'.
- Break: Write jwt_attacker.py to forge token and brute-force secret.
tasks.deliverable: New repo `jwt-security-lab` with API source and attacker script.
tasks.done: Definition of Done: Attacker script gains admin access via both flaws.

tasks.name: Skill: Secure the JWT API
tasks.details:
What: Fixing the flaws.
How to Practice ($0):
- Secure: Create branch 'patched'.
- Fix 1: Only accept HS256.
- Fix 2: Use complex key.
- Verify: Attacker script must fail.
tasks.deliverable: Patched branch with README explaining fixes.
tasks.done: Definition of Done: Exploit works on main but fails on patched branch.

phases.title: Capstone - Exploit-Verified CI/CD
phases.description: Why: Tie everything into one 'Resume Weapon'. Build, Break, Secure lifecycle.

tasks.name: Project: The 'Build, Break, Secure' Pipeline
tasks.details:
What: GitHub Actions pipeline running exploit script.
Steps:
1. Build Action: .github/workflows/security_test.yml. Build container, run exploit.py.
2. Break: Push vulnerable code. Pipeline MUST fail (RED).
3. Secure: Create branch 'patched', fix code.
4. Proof: Push patched code. Pipeline MUST pass (GREEN).
tasks.deliverable: GitHub URL showing clear history of RED and GREEN builds.
tasks.done: Definition of Done: GitHub Action turns RED on main and GREEN on patched.
